title: Telstra chairman unleashes on NBN, backs Craig Dunn
text:
"It seems a waste of collective resources to be delaying investment in the consumer roll-out to people yet to be connected, and instead be focusing investment in the enterprise market where the NBN's duplicating existing high speed fibre for no service or speed advantage," he said.

"There is little doubt in my mind that were the NBN opened to competition, wholesale broadband prices in Australia would fall materially.

There is little doubt in my mind that were the NBN opened to competition, wholesale broadband prices in Australia would fall materially — John Mullen, Telstra chairman

"Let me be clear that we are not recommending that the nation’s policy settings be changed, but we are just saying that if policy settings are not to change, then both sides should respect their original mandates," he said.

He complained it was "inequitable" that NBN Co was allowed to lay fibre for the business market, when companies like Telstra had been restricted from doing so for the residential market.

His comments come just days after Vocus chief executive Kevin Russell publicly made the same points, bringing to the boil months of simmering resentment in the private sector.

The two telcos complain NBN Co's decision to move into the enterprise market - a strategy first announced a year ago - is a breach of its mandate to act as a wholesale only residential fibre network. NBN Co and the federal government reject this argument.

Mr Mullen went on to complain about the cost of reselling the NBN, saying the high wholesale price was unprofitable and causing companies to lose money. He said this meant most NBN retailers would be forced to leave the market.

Advertisement

He said it was also pushing telcos to develop NBN bypass products such as fixed wireless over 4G and 5G mobile networks.

"Ironically, it is actually becoming in the interests of those competitors that are embracing these new technologies that NBN’s prices remain high, so the alternative technologies become more attractive," he said.

"The bottom line of this is that Australia already has some of the highest wholesale broadband pricing in the world, and if this trend continues, over time most resellers of the NBN will withdraw or go broke."

Mr Mullen defended company director and former AMP chief executive Craig Dunn, calling him "one of the best public company directors in the country". He urged shareholders to vote in favour of his re-election. Mr Dunn's association with the scandal ridden wealth company have led to calls for him to be sacked as director.

"We are aware that there has been commentary about Craig’s association with AMP where he was CEO more than six years ago. However, it is important to note that at no time has Craig ever been accused of anything improper himself," Mr Mullen said.

Mr Mullen said Telstra was currently going through its "greatest transformation [it has] has ever undertaken" in its T22 plan.

He said the world of telco monopolies had "gone forever". "Our industry today is exploding into a world of cloud computing, machine learning, artificial intelligence, IoT [Internet of things], autonomous vehicles, big data, drones, satellite technologies, and more," he said.

"This is the new technological world and the old world is not coming back. And while we may not like it, the days of Telstra’s high legacy margins and 100 per cent dividend payout ratio are not coming back either."

Mr Mullen defended chief executive Andy Penn's remuneration package, on which shareholders will also vote.

Outside the convention centre on Tuesday morning, trade unionists were handing out leaflets calling on shareholders to vote down the remuneration report.

CEPU Communications Union National president Shane Murphy said shareholders should send a message that "it is outrageous that the Telstra CEO’s salary continues to rise exorbitantly despite the company a declining share price, slashed dividends and major job losses". As part of the T22 plan, Telstra is cutting a net of 8000 jobs.

Ahead of the vote on Tuesday morning, sources were confident they would go the Telstra board's way.
description: Telstra chairman John Mullen has slammed NBN Co's aggressive move into the enterprise market as a 'waste of collective resources'.
